segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 You're witnessing a miracle unicorn event right now, because I'm not supposed to be here, but here I am.
Hey.
And since I'm not supposed to be here, I have no fucking idea what's going on.
We have slides.
Okay, so let me just tell you a little bit of the history of DC-101.
It's gone up, it's gone down, it's changed.
But really the idea is when we created DEF CON or when I created DEF CON,
everybody just kind of learned from each other.
And we've gotten so large and we've gotten so many sort of myths and stories
that we want to assemble a team here to sort of explain what's real, what's not, how to get the most out of the con,
what we're trying to do with the con, what we're not trying to do.
And you'll hear this phrase over and over at the con, and it's kind of cliche, but it's sort of like the con is what you make of it.
And what we're trying to say with that is look around, like how many thousands of people are here?
You'll get lost in a sea of people unless you find a way to make the con your own experience.
And we try really hard to do that.
So, for example, you'll notice you'll be like in a room of thousands of people.
And you're like, how am I going to, what am I going to do?
Oh, I like physical security.
Oh, I could do tamper evident contest.
I could do lock picking.
Okay, lock picking.
Oh, I think I want to try low security locks.
And next thing you know, you're at a table with ten people picking locks.
So you went from like tens of thousands of people to ten.
And we try really hard to give you all these sort of like off ramp experiences where you can go find other people that are interested in what you're interested in.
And then you're done lock picking, boom, you're back in the crazy stream vortex and you land somewhere else on hacking airplanes.
Right?
And so if you expect the con to come to you, it might not work out so well for you.
But if you just show a little interest and get into a couple of these off ramps, you'll meet amazing people.
By show of hands, who was in Lion Con?
Yeah.
Okay, were you scared?
Did it turn out okay though?
People were probably pretty cool to you in Lion Con.
Right?
That's like the earliest moment of socialization.
Right?
It's okay to ask questions and it's okay to make new friends.
So that's kind of what's going on with Lion Con.
Now, it wasn't planned that way.
It just happened because you had to sit in the Lion Con for so long.
But in the end, it's part of what it means to sort of attend DEF CON.
So with this panel, we mix it up every year, but we want to show you how different people have experienced the con and their advice.
There is no one magic perspective.
Right?
It's so large.
At DEF CON 3, I think, at first I was really angry with myself because people were coming up to me at my own conference and telling me about things I did not see.
And I felt like I'm missing out.
Like, what is the point?
All these people are having these great experiences and I'm hearing about it second hand.
And then at DEF CON 4, I'm like, oh, no, that's a good thing.
Right?
More of that.
And so now, sometimes I'll just secretly scroll on Twitter and I'll be like, awesome, that was cool.
I have no idea what just happened.
And I think you have to sort of take that approach.
Okay.
So I'm going to hand it off to Nikita, who DEF CON would probably not happen without her organizational capabilities.
So with that, Nikita.
Thank you.
Thanks, boss.
Yeah.
So I just wanted to introduce some of the people that are on the panel.
Actually, we talked about maybe them introducing themselves.
So we're going to start with.
Hi, I'm Mar.
Okay.
Hi.
All right.
I'm Mar.
I am the badge designer this year.
And I do art around con.
And you can see it in the hallways and on the signage and stuff.
Hey, I'm Kirsten Renner.
Everyone calls me Krenner.
I had a cooler handle back in the day, but it didn't stick.
I'm mostly known for helping start the car hacking village.
This is our ninth year.
Good evening.
My name is Dilo, and I'm the chief of staff for the SOC.
Hi, I'm five penny, and I'm the vendor lead.
Hi, I'm Megan Wu, and I am the DEF CON workshops lead.
And also in charge of DEF CON workshop CFP.
Thank you, guys.
You said you were the merch lead, and I heard, and I'm a liability.
Okay.
Mar, would you like to come up and talk a little bit about the
badges and the art?
All right.
Hi.
Okay.
So like I said, I'm Mar.
I did the badges this year.
So I just want to talk to you a little bit about how you can
interact with them and what they're all about.
Okay.
So okay.
So the badges, if you've noticed the shape of them, there's a
difference between the inhuman and the human badges.
The human badges are a little bit wider, and the inhumans are
a little bit skinnier.
The reason for this is they're Penrose tiles.
Penrose tiles are pretty geeky if you go on Wikipedia and fall
down a rabbit hole about them, or if you come to my badge talk
tomorrow.
They're an example of aperiodic tiling.
So in physical space, you can actually put them together into
like a big mosaic.
So I wanted people to interact that way with each other with
the badges.
So that's in physical space.
If you look on the back of your badge, there's a URL there.
It's spux.art.
And if you take the little insert that's inside your badge
pack and type in the UUID into the website there, there's a
huge mosaic that's growing right now.
People are doing it.
And every time we add a new person, it just expands.
So we're all making this huge collective piece of art
together.
And hopefully by the end of the con, it's massive and
beautiful.
We'll see what happens.
So once you place your tile, you can place it again as many
times as you want.
So you can get your buddies together and create actual art
instead of just sticking it somewhere.
But we'll see what happens.
OK, so what's next?
Oh, OK.
So the lanyard puzzle.
I don't have a lot to tell you yet about the lanyard puzzle.
But if you look, there's some characters on your lanyards.
There's different characters on the different lanyards.
So try to put it together.
See what you come up with.
OK, and yeah.
So overall, what I'm trying to do with the badge here is just
endless customization.
So you have this chamber on this type of badge.
Even on the other type of badge, if you didn't get one of
these thick plastic badges, there's a little sleeve.
And the inserts will also fit into that little sleeve.
So I pre-released the specs for this little thing.
I'm calling it a shard or an insert.
Call it whatever you like.
Add-on.
Oops, let me drop it on the floor real quick.
It's gone forever.
No, I found it.
It's right here.
So if you look on the back of the program, there's little
pop-out inserts.
So you don't have to create a PCB and be all glowy at con.
The ones that I've seen are really amazing, and you guys are
super creative.
But you can draw your own.
You can cut it from acrylic.
Really anything you want to show off who you are at con.
Okay, and then on that note, the last thing I want to talk
about is galleries and self-expression.
So there's so much art that we see in the hallways and so much
creativity, and hackers and artists are just so similarly
brained in a lot of really interesting ways.
And I think that we should be seeing more of that and give it
more of a dedicated space.
So we've been talking about having a more dedicated gallery
space for the kind of art that you're making in coming years.
So keep an eye out for that.
And that's all I got for you.
I'm sorry I can't stay for the panel, but thank you so much,
and I hope you have a blast.
thank you.
Cheers and applause.
Hey, I'm kay renner.
funny story, and I'm going to roll into how that story, you can take it however you want
on how you may customize your experience and kind of enrich and enhance your engagements,
everyone that you're meeting, whether it's at a talk, or in a line, or at a village,
some of the best engagements are going to be just in the hallway, how you might not
do what I did, unless you want to have an interesting story 15 years later, and then
I'm going to give you a little peek behind the curtain into village ops, and then you
can kind of imagine when I, so I'll name a couple things that kind of are involved in
setting up a village, and I'll forget a whole bunch of things, so multiply it in your head,
and then imagine that there's 40 some odd villages, so I'm telling you about one, and
then multiply that times 50, and then whatever the appropriate multiplier is as you compare
all the things I've got going in my head compared to what, I don't know, Nikita has going in
her head when people don't even let her walk down the hallway, so there we go. So here
goes my story. The person who it's about promised to pretend they remember. I hope
they do, actually. So I'm getting on the plane, somebody handed me some books, and they were
like, you should read this, and one of them was Art of Intrusion, and I was like, what
am I doing, what does hacker mean, what is DEF CON, and I'm doing my research, and I
actually read Hackers for Dummies, and I'm looking on websites, and don't boo me, at the
time I was a recruiter, I was given a list of people to recruit, and the first rule
is, well, first of all, raise your hand if you've never been here. It's friggin' awesome.
Welcome. Welcome. Okay. So someone said what you're going to do is you're going to connect
to some people that have done this before. And those people will kind of help guide you
through and everything. So that's my first tip for you. If you're following Ray Redacted's
Redacted Hunt, flag five is to remember two things I said. So connect to someone who's been
here before to kind of guide you through stuff. Don't let us know if it's an actual emergency.
In the meantime, I'll talk faster. All right. DEF CON, let's go. All right. So fast forward,
I met some people who were amazing. I was very fortunate they kept bringing me to a
lot of cool places and I was just kind of soaking it all in. And I end up, DEF CON was at
Rio at the time. This was DEF CON, I want to say 18. I highly recommend, by the way, going
on YouTube and watching Kristen Padgett's extreme RFID, extreme distance RFID demo. So that
demo was happening on the 30th floor of the Rio. You actually remember? Okay. All right. And
I just ended up in the room. So I'm looking around and it's exciting. There's camera crews
and everything's fun. And I see two people that look familiar. And I'm like, maybe these were
people I was supposed to recruit or something. I don't know. But they look familiar. So I just
walk right up to them and go, hi, I'm Kirsten. You look familiar. And it was you and you were
talking to Dan. And you were very polite about it. You were just kind of like, I don't know,
you probably don't remember. He goes like this. Perfect example. And then they just went
back to their conversation. So I'm glad I added to your content there. But so just real quick,
so that's funny. That's cute. Gave you something to talk about. But I could name a whole bunch
of people. I don't even have to name their handle. I could just say their first name. And you
know, you all know exactly who they are. And I'm not going to go down a whole list of people
because I didn't get permission from them all. I'm not speaking on their behalf. This is my
opinion. But I did get permission from a couple. So if you see Jason, you expect a hug. And he's
kind of obliged to give you one. Right? That's a thing. And if you see Katie's beautiful pink
hair, you want to pick her brain. I can tell you with 15 years of experience, everyone wants to
do that. She's very generous of her time. This is a community united by a passion and a love for
teaching and learning. So everyone that did the research to build the content, to give the
talks, they're constantly trying to build content for you. And they're very generous of their
times. And the bulk of this is on the backs of volunteers. Right? So you're going to notice
things that are broken or wrong in your experience. I kind of recommend letting us know. We
need to know if it's broken or bad. And then you can offer to help. And you can start becoming a
contributor. Right? You can start becoming a part of the community by offering your ideas and
your suggestions and things like that. I keep thinking it's like I said a code word and it's
like you got a point. I'm fucking winning over here. I'm winning. All right. So that's about it.
I don't know if this is in the big DJ slide. Still investigating? All righty. Okay. And the last
thing I'm going to say is everyone you're talking to, make sure you take a moment to look around
you and meet people. Could be the next person that you're going to hire. Could be your next
best friend. One day I accidentally met the CEO of my next company. Pretty cool, huh? So you
are surrounded by greatness and enjoy your show.
Hi, everyone. My name is Dilo and like I said I'm the chief of staff for the SOC department here
with DEF CON. I've been with the SOC for 13 years this year. In my real life I'm a teacher so I
believe that you should be able to read the content without me reading it to you. I'm just
going to add so that you get value add instead of being talked down to. So the 3, 2, 1 rule.
These are guidelines that we ask you to follow. Three hours of sleep a day. Two meals and a
shower. Friends, this is Vegas and it's hot. Please shower and use deodorant and we love you.
Also, because we're in and out of air conditioned rooms, we're in and out of the heat. Con crud
is real. We all go home with the chesty cough and it's just gross. How can we work against
that? Follow the 3, 2, 1 rule and definitely take those showers. Wash your hands. Use
sanitizer, hand sanitizer frequently. And then also maybe limit handshakes. Maybe do an
elbow pump or a fist pump. I work with kids so we do toe taps. Keep it fun and maybe not
transmit so many germs. I also talk really fast so sorry. We also have this safety third
rule. Know your boundaries. Know what works for you. We are in the desert. But the SOC is
really the department of fun enforcement. So we want to make sure that you have fun and in
order to do that, we need to ask you to do a couple things. Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate. And
also drink some electrolytes. If you're going to drink some alcohol, it is DEF CON. People
did shots. Follow that with some water. Alternate back and forth. Make good choices. And
then also try not to put yourself in danger. If you find yourself in a situation, it happens.
Look for a red shirt. All goons wear red shirts. But not all red shirts are SOC goons. So if
you find yourself in a situation, ask a red shirt to put you in contact with a SOC goon. We will
gladly meet with you, talk with you, find out what you're upset about or what kind of help you
need. And in addition to that, as a part of our SOC team, we have the hotline. So if you
DEF CON believes that your mental and physical health are important. Sorry, I'm just
reading a note. Here are some reasons to call the hotline. Are you struggling with a mental
health issue? Are you feeling scared or worried about your physical safety? Do you want to
voice a concern? Would you like to report a code of conduct violation anonymously if you
preferred? We have a phone number. It's up there. All the places. We also have a discord
channel called DEF CON hotline and there's an email that you can email your concerns to at
safety at DEF CON dot org. Those are all the ways you can find the hotline. So also in terms
of safety, these hallways, we've got stanchions and we've got flagging tape and people are
walking in different directions. Just take a minute, put your phone in your pocket, look up,
look where you're going and try and stay to the right. That will help traffic move easily. And
let's talk about some respect, friends. Because you know what? We are a community and we all
just really are here to learn and get to know each other and get to know more about the
community. So let's be mindful that when you're taking pictures, please be, if you're going to
do it, I mean we know you do it. There's a photo policy. We ask you to follow it. There's a
whole code of conduct thing. So you know, maybe read it and try and follow it. But if you're
going to hold your phone and you're going to take a picture, be obnoxious about it and be
like hey I'm about to take a picture. If you don't want to be in it, turn your face away. If
you see someone's pointing their camera at you, turn your face away. If you notice that
someone took a picture of you and you're very uncomfortable with that, please say
something. Hey, excuse me, you know what? I really wasn't prepared to be in that. Do you
mind deleting it? Friends, if someone comes up to you and says hey, could you delete that?
Be nice. Be respectful and say you know what? Sure. Not a problem. So that we're respecting
each other. That would be really great. Let's see, what else? Don't be afraid to get to know
the people around you. As you're introducing yourselves, you're standing in lines and you get
to meet new friends. Be approachable. Hey, you know what? It was so great to meet you. Can I
give you a hug? Consent is key, my friends. Say it again for the people in the back. Consent is
key. So if you're going to hug, if you're going to touch someone in some way, please, please,
please ask for consent. Because if you don't, then they call us and then we get to find and
talk to you. That was it for me. So I'm glad you guys are here. Thank you so much for
asking me to be a part of this panel. Like I said, this is my 13th year but this is my first
time speaking. But I have to go back to work after so I did not take a shot. So everyone
could raise a drink and take one for me. That would be great. Thanks.
Hi, I'm 5penny. I am not much of a public speaker so I'm going to do my best here. So this
year we have vendors as well as exhibitors. Exhibitors are a new department for us. They don't
sell anything. It's more kind of like a classic trade show. And they sponsor the non-profits that
you will see throughout the vendor room this year. The vendor room also has a non-profit
corner that you guys should definitely check out and visit. Excuse me.
Thank you guys for being so supportive. I'm definitely an introvert. I didn't know I was going
to be doing this. So we also have communities in the non-profit area of the vendor room this
year. Some of you will recognize such as WISP. And in the vendor area, you'll see a lot of
stuff out on the table. The vendors are very friendly. They want to talk to everybody about their
products. But that doesn't mean what you're seeing is free. So definitely when you're talking to
the vendors, engage with them. Make sure that the swag is available to take and it's not actually
a product. And I think that's it.
I don't want to be here. Do you? Hey, everyone. I'm so excited to be here. I'm so excited
to be here. So as you all know, we have a lot of content across all of the properties here at
Caesars, Harrah's, Link and Flamingo. Obviously as the workshop's lead, I usually don't leave
Flamingo a lot since that's where our workshops are at. But what I would recommend as we get
into the main days of the con on Friday and Saturday and then before closing on Sunday is take
some time and review the program, the schedules, the list of things, the talks, vendors,
contests and events, all of that. And try to pick a couple of things that would interest you.
Download the hacker tracker app so that way you can stay on top of things. And also hop on to
DEF CON social or the forums and try to find out what other folks are interested in and what
they're doing here at con. When I started coming to DEF CON, Twitter was pretty brand new.
So that was how we would find out where everybody was congregating, which bar everyone was
hanging out at, what talks folks were most interested to see, what villages were doing the
coolest stuff. And then we would meet there. So DEF CON social is kind of taking that place
now. And if all else fails, have a backup plan. So we have DC TV playing across a lot of the
hotel properties. And we have five channels. And it really beats standing in line. Especially
like Saturday morning when you might be a little hungover or the end of Saturday afternoon or
Friday afternoon if you're feeling really overwhelmed, especially as a lot of like
introverts and amberverts. We're surrounded by people. There's constant stimulation. We just
need a moment. But we don't want that FOMO. We have DC TV and we also have Twitch. So at
main stage we have four main tracks with about 120 talks. There's something for everybody. But
not all talks are for everybody. So as well as being the head of the workshop CFP, I'm a
member of the main stage CFP review board. And what we try to do is take all the proposals,
review them and try to figure out what's interesting, what's novel, what do we think that you
as the attendees might have the most interest in. So we ask that you guys keep that in
mind. And don't heckle the speakers. Especially since a lot of us, like I said, are
introverts and amberverts and it's hard enough to just get up on the stage. So if you have a
question or a comment, save it for after the talk. Approach them and be like, hey, let me buy
you a coffee or beverage of your choice. I have some questions or I want to talk about your
talk. Most people are really receptive to that and it's less hostile than being heckled during
like your first DEF CON talk. Then we also have workshops. So this year we are located at
the bottom floor of the Flamingo. We have five sessions a day on Thursday, today, Friday and
Saturday. They usually run from 9 a.m. until 6 p.m. And we cover everything from red team,
blue team, mobile app sec. We have our first policy workshop this year. So we're really
excited about that. Most of them sell out within minutes. This year we had a couple that
sold out within hours. So it's really hard to get a seat in them. But on the forums we do
have a thread that people, if they're cancelling their pre-reg, they let folks know like,
hey, I have a ticket for swap and I can transfer it over to you if you want to go to this
workshop. Otherwise we don't have a wait list. So please don't fill up the hallway. We would
really appreciate that. And now it's Nikita's turn.
Thank you, Megan. Okay. I'm going to talk a little bit about some pro-tips and
some advice I thought I would put together after asking someone who it was their first
DEF CON. And these questions came up. So that's why they're here. After I finish my portion
of the talk, we're going to open up to a short Q&A. There are, there's a mic in the center aisle
here. So if you have a question that you want to ask, you might want to consider lining up for
it in case it gets long. I don't know if it will. So one of my advice is don't forget your
CON badge. We're not going to replace it if you lose it. If you lost it, we're sorry for you.
That's really bad. But we're not going to give you a new one. We're, if you are walking around
with a counterfeit badge, we're going to take that out and SOC's going to have a couple of
conversations with you. If you are coming down to the parties, bring your badge. It is
required. A lot of people dress up. They don't think about it. They're wearing nice clothes or
dresses or, you know, cosplay or whatever. And you forget to bring your badge. And then you
have to take the long walk back. And it sucks. Ask me how I know. I don't know how I know.
So the gentleman I talked to about said, what's the one thing you used to forget to do all the
time? And I said, not get too drunk. So after I was done working, you know, I would go out to
the sky boxes or the parties just like anybody else. And before you know it, you might have
had a little bit too much. And one of those experiences in the Riviera, I was the mobile
bartender. So I had a messenger bag. I don't advise you to do this, by the way. I had a
messenger bag lined and filled with ice, disposable cups, mixers and various forms of
alcohol. So people would come up to me and say, hey, make me a drink. Sorry, boss. And I
would do that. And I would take the straw and taste it to make sure it was okay. Never sample
your own product. It hit me like the wave of the heat when you exit out of the airplane. And I
said, I got to go. Peace out. And I almost didn't make it to my room. I ran into a goon. I
want to say his name was John Q. Public, but I'm not entirely sure. And he was like, oh,
yeah, we're not going to leave you alone here. So he helped me get to my room. But if
something feels wrong, like if you have a suspicion that I only had one drink, why do I feel
like this, you might want to go and take a rest, maybe talk to a goon, say I don't feel good.
Something's wrong. And then they'll take it from there. They have a whole process and
checklist. But, yeah, that was a funny story for me. Just passing the advice on. Sanitary
supplies, tampons, menstrual pads, they are in both bathrooms. You don't have to use a
bathroom. You can use whatever bathroom you identify with. This year we have a sticker
wall. Please use it. Please. Yes, please use it. And the last thing that I wanted to tell
you about is how to get the most out of DEF CON. And what I would say for that is don't be
hard on yourself for having to do certain things. Like you make a plan and you're like, no, I'm
supposed to go here, but this vortex wants me to go hang out over here. Just go with the
vortex. Go where your heart wants. You don't have to feel guilty about missing a talk. We'll
publish it online for free. You can watch it later. Don't feel bad about not getting the
opportunity to visit one of the 32 villages. It's a lot. It's over ‑‑ it's half a million
square feet. So it's a lot to walk around. Which reminds me, wear comfortable shoes. Don't
think, oh, these are nice sketchers, air walks or whatever. They have to get you miles. Some
of our goons put on 14 miles a day. So it's a lot of walking and it's a lot of moving
about. But back to that. Some ‑‑ some of you are here because your employer ‑‑
okay. He said it twice so he could get applause. He said it twice so he could get applause.
Twice. Okay. No, no, no. I'm sorry. So some of you are here because maybe your employer
decided to foot the bill this year. And that's fair. Especially if you're new. It's a safer
bet to give us a chance to experience it when your employer is paying for some of the bill. No
judgment. However, don't think about what does my employer want to see me do? What does
he want to see from me when I get back? Like what did I learn? Because you are going to be
really over ‑‑ overwhelmed with all of the information and the things that you learn. So
instead try to look at it as what did I learn I can learn? What things interest you and
inspires you to make something better at work or for your team or to inspire you to take on a
new project. Which leads me to this question. When you're walking around DEF CON, I want
you to think what do you want to spend the next 12 months doing until you come back? A lot of
you will flip from one end to the other and you'll see lots of things and get inspired to
want to make a contest or do that thing better. We will be opening our call for contests almost
immediately after the close. Thank you. No. I'm talking. I'm talking. I'm talking. I'm
talking. Okay. Thank you. It's funny. I'm the person that can text to make that go away.
But I'm on stage. Okay. So yeah. Our call for contests will be opening almost immediately
after the CON is over. We have forums that currently have a whole bunch of different
channels where you can interact with the contests now. If you want to contribute to what they're
doing, grow upon it, add upon it, reach out and interact. There's nothing wrong with introducing
yourself. That's just normal here. Nobody is like too unapproachable or too big or too rock
star. That's not the culture that we support. We support knowledge and engagement and walking
into a village knowing nothing and walk out knowing at least one thing. So now I think we have
a lot of time left on the clock. But if we'd like to open it up to any questions, you could yell
really loud or go to the mic. Thank you. Questions? Okay. So I'm going to go ahead and
start. Let's see if they'll turn on your microphone. Testing. Okay. Thank you all for putting
this on. In terms of FOMO, is it pretty safe to assume that all the main stage talks will be
recorded? And then what about the villages and the talks there? Yeah. So all the main stage
talks will be recorded and captioned in English and then published later at some point as
fast as we can. And some villages. I think do you know which ones? Yeah. There's a few
villages that are having recorded talks in our track 5 which is kind of like near the contest
area. So some talks from car hacking village, AR, XR village, a few others. And there are
some individual villages recording like APSEC and I honestly can't remember. But they do exist.
Okay. Thank you very much. One question. Okay. Anybody next? If not, we'll just tell you
stories. Okay. So raise your hand if it's your first DEF CON. I know. Raise your hand if
you're international. Okay. Now raise your hand if you're a fed. Okay. Raise your hand if
you're a fed. Oh, I saw it. Oh, yeah. How do you decide when you add more villages? So you
might have noticed some people talking. We constantly are sort of renewing and changing
villages. And villages come and go based on their size, the maturity of their group, maybe
the people put together have moved on with jobs. So it's constant. Everything is in sort of
constant renewal. But we've tried to put a focus on villages to be hands on. So the
villages aren't just another speaking track. But you can walk into a village, do a thing, and
then you're like, hey, I just learned how to do the thing. And that's sort of the idea of a
village. And so sometimes people will tell you about how it was three years ago. But we're
really trying to get more hands on in villages and trying to move talks and other kinds of
events into different spaces. So what we do is we look at all the villages we have, a new
submission will come in, and we'll see, well, what's the history of the people involved? Is it a
good idea? Like, what was it? Like the automated marijuana growers village. And you're like,
what is that? And you look at it, and it's like, oh, it's automation, it's industrial
control, it's all these microcontrollers. And you're like, oh, that's pretty neat. And you
try it for a year. And you realize nobody really went. People got those skills in other
villages. And you're like, okay, well, that didn't work. So we'll give that space to somebody
else the next year. So a lot of times we give you just enough rope to hang yourself and try it
out. And if you show improvement, we'll give you more space. And that's why when you see
villages that have a lot of space, that's because they've been repeatedly really good at
delivering. And small villages don't mean they're bad, it just might mean they're new. And
we follow the same thing for contests and events. But as Nikita will tell you, there's only so
much space, and so we have to make really hard decisions about which villages we're
accepting. There's a bunch of villages we would want to accept we don't have space for,
essentially. Boy, the bass is really kicking. So I actually bothered to come find a
microphone. But as a first timer, you got any cool swag you want to give me because I
bothered to ask? A first timer? I thought maybe you were saying first in line. No, but you can
buy a car hacking village badge in the morning if you get there fast enough. And our theme is
back to the future. Look at that flux capacitor. Thanks, guys. Yeah, thank you. Hi. I
wanted to ask, so I have some experience in things such as like safe spaces and stuff like
that. And so the SOC team sounds interesting to me, even though this is like my first time at
DEF CON. So my question is, how would someone join that? Or how much experience would they need
to have for it? Yeah, so your question goes more to how do you become a goon? And it would be
interesting to hear everybody's stories on how, if they are a goon, how they became a goon
because there are many paths to goondom. Okay, hi. So there are a lot of different
departments that have goons. Like I said, all goons wear red shirts. So some of you have
a lot of interest in certain things. And like you said, you might be interested in being a
SOC goon. What I recommend is that, I personally recommend that you tend a minimum of three
DEF CONs as an attendee before you think about even coming on staff. And the reason is this,
every year DEF CON is just a little bit different and we grow so much in that time. And you
have the opportunity to see and experience and learn new things. And what you think today
might be really interesting, next year you might learn something else. You're like, oh, but I
kind of like that too. So it gives you a chance to learn and see and really kind of get to know
what the CON is all about. And then I would say, meet the people who do that job. If you are
interested in becoming a SOC goon, meet us. Say hi to us. Ask us why we do what we do. And
find out if it's really for you. Because it sounds really fun until you realize that,
friends, I got, I did not follow the 3-2-1 rule. I got one hour and 38 minutes of sleep
yesterday. Because it took that much to get my department going. I have a department of
150 people that keep you guys rolling through the weekend. So there's a lot to do. If you
enjoy being on your feet for 12 hours a day and standing in a three foot space answering the
same question 85 million times a day, then maybe the SOC is for you or info booth. But if
that doesn't interest you, then there's a lot of other things that you can do. But again, I
would say, observe, experience, ask questions. Thank you. Hi. Sorry. I just have a quick
question. There's a few talks that I'm really interested in. They are the virtual hospital in
space, hacking reproductive health, the microbiome. They all said that they're virtual
talks but I can't seem to find the links for them and I'm just wondering when I can watch
those. Have you checked on hacker tracker? Yeah, they're on hacker tracker. They're
virtual. They're listed for midnight last night but there's no other information. Which
village is it? I think it's the bioengineering. Oh, the biohacking village? Biohacking,
sorry. They most likely might be on the discord or on one of their own twitches. You might
want to check out the info booth and see if you can get a little bit more information from
them. They might be able to help. Okay. Thank you. Yeah. I'm just wondering if you
have any questions. I know. He asked if there's more than one way to ‑‑ more than one
path to becoming a goon if we were interested in talking about that. Oh, ours.
Okay. He wants our stars specifically. No. We've never had a talk about that. I can tell you my
story. It's kind of funny if you want to hear it. My first DEF CON was DEF CON 18. I went to
the pool at the Riviera. And then we moved to the Rio and then I met a bunch of friends and I
was like, oh, hey, okay. So, again, don't do what I did. But I became a shadow goon. I
basically kind of watched what they did and I thought, you know what, I have a lot of really
interpersonal experience and I have a lot of crowd control experience. Once upon a moon I
worked for Disney so I can move a crowd of people. And so they just were like, all right,
clear this hallway. And so I did. And they were like, okay, cool. Come back tomorrow. So, I did
that. And then I have a personal motto. My personal motto is how can I make your day better?
And so that really kind of ‑‑ I kind of went into the sock with, hey, how can I make your day
better? And they were like, hey, how can you not make our day better? And I basically started ‑‑
this was back before the no outside food or beverage was really enforced. We all remember those
days. I used to make handmade sandwiches and lunches for the sock goons back when we were a
department of 75. So I made 75 meals for four days. 75 meals a day for four days for our team. And
that was how I could make their day better, which was to keep them fed and hydrated while they
were on the floor. And as I did that, more and more things became evident that things needed to
be done within our department. And so there's a hole, I'm going to fill it. So I just started
taking on new responsibilities. And here we are 13 years later, I'm the, you know, the chief of
staff for a department of 150 and we're one of the largest of the DEF CON departments. So it
really does show, like, you just have a skill and you bring it where it's needed and then you
find a hole and you fill it.
Hi. Yeah, so this is my first DEF CON. And I was pretty surprised to see so many people and
especially so many people carrying cash and paying in cash. So I was wondering about the
backstory of managing cash. So first, did you ever think of switching to something else, like
for example, Bitcoin or or just outright credit cards or whatever? And also, how do you get all
that cash out? And I mean, what do you do with the cash?
That's pretty sus of you to ask.
Yeah, I know. I know. But that's why I mean, I think it's entertaining. It would be
entertaining to know.
It is a production, but it is a classified production. But I would say that one of the reasons
why that we have our registration system as a cash based by design is to protect the privacy of
people that are otherwise unable to or concerned about putting their name in a registry that could
then be subpoenaed or collected. That kind of has always been the culture for Jeff. You know,
things are really good now. There's support and encouragement. We've got policy village. We've got
people wanting to interact with us. But back in the days when Jeff started this and for quite a
while, it was, you didn't want the feds to know who you were. They were a little bit out to get
you. But as far as cryptocurrency is concerned, no.
Thank you.
Thank you.
It's hard.
Yeah, there was, I think it was mentioned in the DEF CON documentary. At one point, the hotel we
were staying at, Alexis Park, there was some sort of, we never knew what it turned out to be, but it
was a counterterrorism investigation, supposedly. And they pulled the records of everybody that
stayed at all the convention hotels and anybody that paid with a credit card. And we'd never even
got a subpoena, because it was so well known, everything was cash, there was nothing to get. And
so that probably saved us hundreds of thousands of dollars of legal fees by just not collecting it
in the first place. So I'm a big believer in this whole, like, if you can't protect it, don't
collect it, because it saved us.
And real quick, to the person who asked about the schedule, HackerTracker already heard your
question and are already fixing it. Yes.
We want people waiting in line at the microphone to get priority just so everybody can hear them.
Howdy. I've got a question from the Discord. Someone wanted to know about what went into the
decision for forum communities and how does it affect the communities, villages, exhibitors,
et cetera, divide. And then also, what communities are there? Wow, spiking is weird.
Yeah, so the community idea is sort of a work in progress. But the idea is, what's the EFF? We put
the EFF in the vendor room and they would, for donations, they'd give you some stickers and
stuff. But really they're there to grow their community and explain to the community what is the
EFF doing, what are they working on, what are their priorities. And then you would have other
community groups, right? Say again? Yeah, you had women in WISP, women information security
professionals. You would have other groups that are organizing and trying to find other people
interested in their projects. You would have, say, maybe, what was the university? Yeah, UAT.
But you would have people that were clearly not selling something, so they're not really a
vendor. And they're not really running a contest. But it's really important that they find
their people and communicate with what they're doing. ACLU, whatever. So we decided what we
were doing is we were taking communities essentially and forcing them to fit in either the
vendor zone or a village. And it just wasn't working. And so instead what we need to do is
listen to what their needs are and if it's just tables and a place to meet and talk, then why
force them to follow all the requirements for a village. So that's what we're trying, right?
We're trying to figure out the needs of communities that want to meet and organize but aren't
really selling a thing or running a track of hands on. That's the idea.
Thank you.
Hello. Hi. First DEF CON. Glad to be here. Thank you for everything you guys do. I've got a
kind of important question, though. So in the book that I got, it basically said, okay, goons
are wearing red shirts and they have on hours and off hours. And when they're on hours, they
don't drink. And then they have off hours and they can drink. Obviously everybody wants to
buy a goon a drink. But that didn't really discuss all the rest of the staff that aren't
wearing red shirts. A number of you up there aren't. What's the policy that applies to the
rest of you as far as drinking? Yeah, so, I mean, I don't drink during CON hours. I don't
know if Nikita does. You probably shouldn't. I'm fucking with you. Just fucking with her.
And so to your first part, the red shirt, some people we don't wear red shirts because if we
did, we would never be able to get down the hallway. And so as like the HQ staff, the staff
that's responsible for paying the bills and making some of the stuff happen, it's really
important that we get around quickly. For operational departments, yeah, they need to be
visible. And, you know, sometimes people do drink. And if you see it, I don't want you to
knock them out, but we definitely can't have drunk goons in red shirts. That is no, no, no,
no, no. That's a huge liability problem. That's not what we're about. So if you do see
violations, please let us know because we need to be held accountable. And if you don't see
us being held accountable, then you're not going to ‑‑ you're not really going to back us up.
You're not going to believe what we say. So we try to create a system where we have a code
of conduct. We have a transparency report to show you that we're holding ourselves
accountable. And you'll see in that transparency report every year usually we let a goon go.
Right? Because they've misbehaved. So the rules apply to us just as it applies to everybody
else. I can definitely say that as a ‑‑ there's a reason I didn't take a shot. Like I
said, you know, first time speakers take a shot, but I have to go back to work. And so I
felt like that would be violating the piece of paper that I signed when I came here that
said that I won't drink while I'm on duty. So I hold myself accountable to that. I hold our
team accountable to that. You know, I don't let the sock goons drink in the red shirt. If
you see them off duty, you know, we all have the red badge. So if they're in a red shirt,
that means they're on duty and we're here for you. Especially the sock team. We are the
department of fun enforcement. We want to make sure that you are having a good time and
that you are safe. And we can't do that if we are not ‑‑ if we're inebriated or under the
influence in some way. So we just try to hold ourselves to that standard. Other departments
I also believe have kind of the same conduct because we sign that code of conduct that says
that we're not going to be inebriated or under the influence while we're working. But again,
I can't speak for other departments. I just speak for sock. Okay. Well, thank you. We're
going to wrap it up now. Last question. Oh, I thought it was you. Go ahead. Sorry. Just
one clarifying question about how badges work. I also knew that cash was the main payment
method. But it seems like this year people that pre‑register, pre‑bid card got like a
full real badge. But people that pay with cash got the paper badge that doesn't even have
like the puzzle or any of the interactions. So how does that work? Well, it's not supposed to
work that way. Unfortunately that's how it's worked so far. So what happens is one of the
things that we can count on is when people pre‑register, we know they're coming. They've
given us money. And so we know how to allocate the resources. And so as we were getting badge
shipments and then we started having problems with the badge manufacturer, we had barely
enough for the people who even pre‑reg. We don't think of the pre‑reg people as anything
different. It's just it happened that the number of pre‑regs was just slightly less the
number of real badges we got. It's not a policy or anything that they get it and others
don't. And so I'll talk about it more tomorrow. We're still getting more information from the
manufacturer who has been very, very slow, I should say. Right now we're investigating
flying somebody in an airplane to physically fly on Saturday with more badges from the
manufacturing facility. We're trying every angle we could possibly try. And as we get more
physical badges over the next couple of days, what we'll do is we'll swap out the badges for
real badges. And we'll just keep doing that until we've run out of people on airplanes. But,
you know. Thank you. Okay. Oh, you're sneaking in a question? No, you're not. Okay,
great. So I want to thank you all for coming. We're all approachable if you see us. But if you
see us heads down running down the hallway, please don't be in our way. We might storm right
over you. Again, it is what you make of it. I hope that's something you take away. Yeah.
No, no, I thought you were going to say something. That's okay. And so one thing that we try to
do when you're thinking about the difference, what's the difference between DEF CON and say
any other infosec conference, when we do look at villages or contests or events or anything,
we always say, is that hacker? Like, it doesn't have to advance your career. Being here is
not necessarily about upskilling yourself for your next job. Here is where you recharge your
creativity and try something new and meet new people. And so that's why we sort of try to
be, that's what we mean when we say more hacker. Your company doesn't care if you learn how to
hack a PS3. But here it might be really fun, right? And so that's what we're about. The
mindset, not necessarily the latest, you know, attack against an Oracle database. So,
thanks a lot. Thanks to the panel. And see you at DEF CON.
